summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting a gag order under Local Criminal Rule 23.1. The letter argues that the government, its agents, and attorneys for prospective witnesses have made prejudicial public statements that threaten Maxwell's right to a fair trial, citing specific comments from the Acting U.S. Attorney, an FBI Special Agent, and several plaintiffs' attorneys.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, who is accused of sex trafficking and related crimes in connection with Jeffrey Epstein. The letter is written on her behalf to request a gag order.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York. The letter is addressed to her.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., who is one of Ghislaine Maxwell's defense lawyers and the signatory of this letter.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who held a press conference on July 2, 2020, commenting on Maxwell's alleged crimes and credibility, which the defense cites as prejudicial.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Attorney representing several witnesses/accusers in the matter. The letter cites multiple public statements he made commenting on Maxwell's potential cooperation, guilt, and trial strategy, which the defense argues are prejudicial.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Partner of David Boies who also represents witnesses. The letter cites her public statements about the pain caused by Maxwell and her role as a central figure in Epstein's crimes.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing witnesses who made public statements following Maxwell's arrest, characterizing her as the main facilitator of Epstein's organization and speculating about her cooperation.

persons.name: Allison Moe
persons.context: Attorney with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, copied on the letter.

persons.name: Mark Cohen
persons.context: Attorney with Cohen & Gresser LLP, copied on the letter.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney with Cohen & Gresser LLP, copied on the letter.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney with Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., copied on the letter.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and alleged co-conspirator. The charges against Maxwell are in connection with Epstein's sex trafficking ring. He is referenced throughout as the primary perpetrator Maxwell allegedly assisted.

connections.description: Described as working 'hand-in-hand' to facilitate crimes over decades, with Maxwell allegedly playing a critical role in identifying and grooming victims for Epstein.
Pagliuca is a defense attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman writing this letter on behalf of their client, Ghislaine Maxwell.
Partners at a law firm who both represent several witnesses/accusers in the Maxwell case.
Boies, as attorney for accusers, is an adversarial party making public statements about Maxwell's guilt, credibility, and potential trial strategy.
Strauss, as the Acting U.S. Attorney, is the lead prosecutor bringing charges against Maxwell and made public statements about the allegations.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested in a raid at her New Hampshire residence. Acting U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss held a press conference announcing the charges.

events.title: Detention Hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: A detention hearing was held regarding Maxwell's bail. Following the hearing, attorney David Boies commented on the proceedings.

events.title: Defense Files Motion for Gag Order
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys filed this letter with the court requesting an order prohibiting extrajudicial statements by the government and witnesses' counsel.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007 (United States District Court, Southern District of New York)
New Hampshire (location of Ghislaine Maxwell's residence where she was arrested)
Denver, Colorado (location of Haddon, Morgan and Foreman law firm)
New Mexico (referenced as an isolated ranch location where an accuser was allegedly taken)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is formally requesting a gag order to prevent the government and witnesses' attorneys from making prejudicial public statements.

The defense cites specific, allegedly prejudicial comments made by Acting U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss, an FBI Special Agent, and plaintiffs' attorneys David Boies, Sigrid McCawley, and Bradley Edwards.
The defense argues the government staged a media-focused arrest raid instead of a 'plain vanilla surrender' to generate prejudicial publicity.

The letter references Local Criminal Rule 23.1, which prohibits public discussion of seven specific topics deemed likely to interfere with a fair trial, including the defendant's character, witness credibility, and opinions on guilt.
The document reveals active public relations and legal strategy battles occurring in the media parallel to the court proceedings in the Maxwell case.
